lines.text: [Music]
Last time on Trebuchet Village.
Our heroes finally bested the terrible Kitsunes, the clown Sasquatch, and the jester himself once and for all.
It was a long, hard-fought battle, but the win was secured by some clever use of fog, some well-placed arrows, and powerful thunks with a big shovel.
Afterwards, the gang freed the Kugler elf slaves and returned to the White Woman of the
Woods, where she named a pond, sort of after the brave adventurers who freed Whippet Woods
of its jester menace.
There was drinking, limbo, dancing, singing, and even a wedding.
While the festivities raged on, the world took notice, in some small, irreversible way,
of the impact Dogen, Patric, and Evil have had on the ye olde planet E-Bow.
Once they left the woods, the boys were faced with the awesome sight of their beloved Terrafire
Kingdom in the silhouette of a one-claw castle.
However, with the sudden disappearance of Mount Honestoodle, an unease fell upon the party,
but nevertheless they persisted.
Due northeast, specifically, towards Trebyshe village, but also a little bit towards the
disputed part of the Terrafire Kingdom.
While the west of the trebuchet landmass is largely left alone, and the south unexplored,
the east in large part belongs to the Terrafire Kingdom.
However, where the north contends with scaredy cats and brave lions, among other things of
course, the east contends with those who disagree with King Nardwar's leniency towards the
scaredy cats.
Sure, there is dissent across the kingdom in one small way or another, but the east lies
in the city of Galgadot, a bastion for all the most vile of the kingdom, and the rise of
a new lord who wishes to challenge King Nardwar. But Galgadot is quite far out, and although
its reach can be felt where our heroes are, it's nothing they need to concern themselves
about right now. In fact, what they should be concerning themselves with is that they've
been traveling for three days and haven't seen a soul. The road ahead and its signs do
suggest that there are some small towns nearby, but the lack of any other travelers and the
hours spent hunting and gathering food can be tiresome. Here's hoping the future brings
something more substantial to eat and to do as they get closer and closer to their home.
